slides.content:
# Introduction to Environmental Chemistry üåç

Welcome to **Environmental Chemistry** - understanding the chemical processes that affect our planet!

## What you'll learn:
- **Pollution Types** - Air, water, and soil contamination
- **Greenhouse Effect** - Climate change chemistry
- **Ozone Layer** - Formation and depletion
- **Green Chemistry** - Sustainable solutions

> üí° **Fun Fact:** The atmosphere contains only 0.04% CO‚ÇÇ, yet this small amount controls Earth's temperature!

## Why Environmental Chemistry?
- üå°Ô∏è **Climate change** - Understanding and solutions
- üíß **Clean water** - Essential for life
- üå¨Ô∏è **Air quality** - Public health
- ‚ôªÔ∏è **Sustainability** - Future generations

## Earth's Spheres

| Sphere | Description | Chemical Focus |
|--------|-------------|----------------|
| Atmosphere | Air layer | Gases, pollution |
| Hydrosphere | Water bodies | Water chemistry |
| Lithosphere | Land and soil | Soil chemistry |
| Biosphere | Living things | Biochemical cycles |

## The Challenge

Human activities are altering Earth's chemistry at unprecedented rates.

Let's understand the science behind environmental issues!

slides.title: Air Pollution
slides.content:
# Air Pollution üå´Ô∏è

## Major Air Pollutants

| Pollutant | Formula | Sources | Effects |
|-----------|---------|---------|--------|
| Carbon monoxide | CO | Incomplete combustion | Reduces O‚ÇÇ in blood |
| Sulfur dioxide | SO‚ÇÇ | Burning fossil fuels | Acid rain |
| Nitrogen oxides | NO‚Çì | Vehicles, power plants | Smog, acid rain |
| Particulate matter | PM | Burning, industry | Respiratory disease |
| Ozone (ground level) | O‚ÇÉ | Photochemical smog | Lung damage |
| Volatile organics | VOCs | Solvents, fuels | Cancer risk |

## Smog Formation

### Photochemical Smog (Brown smog)

```
NO‚ÇÇ + sunlight ‚Üí NO + O
O + O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí O‚ÇÉ (ground-level ozone)

NO‚Çì + VOCs + sunlight ‚Üí Smog
```

### Sulfurous Smog (Gray/London smog)

```
Coal burning + fog ‚Üí Smoke + SO‚ÇÇ
```

## Health Effects

| Pollutant | Short-term | Long-term |
|-----------|------------|----------|
| CO | Headache, dizziness | Heart disease |
| SO‚ÇÇ | Breathing problems | Bronchitis |
| O‚ÇÉ | Coughing, chest pain | Lung damage |
| PM | Eye/throat irritation | Cancer, death |

## Air Quality Index (AQI)

| AQI | Level | Color |
|-----|-------|-------|
| 0-50 | Good | Green |
| 51-100 | Moderate | Yellow |
| 101-150 | Unhealthy for sensitive | Orange |
| 151-200 | Unhealthy | Red |
| 201-300 | Very unhealthy | Purple |
| 300+ | Hazardous | Maroon |

> üéØ **Key Point:** Most air pollution comes from burning fossil fuels!

slides.title: Water Pollution
slides.content:
# Water Pollution üíß

## Types of Water Pollutants

| Type | Examples | Sources |
|------|----------|---------|
| **Pathogens** | Bacteria, viruses | Sewage |
| **Nutrients** | N, P compounds | Fertilizers |
| **Heavy metals** | Pb, Hg, Cd | Industry |
| **Organic chemicals** | Pesticides, solvents | Agriculture, industry |
| **Thermal** | Heat | Power plant cooling |
| **Sediment** | Soil particles | Erosion |

## Eutrophication

```
Excess nutrients (N, P)
        ‚Üì
Algal bloom (rapid growth)
        ‚Üì
Algae die and decompose
        ‚Üì
Bacteria consume O‚ÇÇ
        ‚Üì
Fish and organisms die
        ‚Üì
    "Dead zone"
```

## Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD)

```
BOD = Oxygen needed to decompose organic matter
```

| BOD (mg/L) | Water Quality |
|------------|---------------|
| < 3 | Good |
| 3-6 | Moderate pollution |
| > 6 | Polluted |

## Heavy Metal Pollution

| Metal | Source | Effect |
|-------|--------|--------|
| Lead (Pb) | Old pipes, paint | Neurological damage |
| Mercury (Hg) | Coal, mining | Minamata disease |
| Arsenic (As) | Natural, industry | Cancer |
| Cadmium (Cd) | Batteries, plating | Kidney damage |

## Biomagnification

```
    Toxin accumulates up food chain:
    
    Water (1x) ‚Üí Algae (10x) ‚Üí Fish (100x) ‚Üí Bird (1000x)
```

> üí° **Warning:** Top predators accumulate the highest toxin levels!

slides.title: Soil Pollution
slides.content:
# Soil Pollution üå±

## Sources of Soil Pollution

| Source | Pollutants introduced |
|--------|----------------------|
| Agriculture | Pesticides, fertilizers |
| Industry | Heavy metals, chemicals |
| Waste disposal | Plastics, organics |
| Mining | Heavy metals, acids |
| Oil spills | Hydrocarbons |

## Pesticide Persistence

| Type | Half-life | Example |
|------|-----------|--------|
| Short-lived | Days | Organophosphates |
| Moderate | Weeks-months | Carbamates |
| Persistent | Years | DDT, HCHs |

## DDT - A Cautionary Tale

- Developed 1939, widely used
- Killed malaria mosquitoes effectively
- BUT: Persistent, bioaccumulates
- Caused bird eggshell thinning
- Banned 1972 (many countries)

## Soil pH Effects

| pH | Effect on metals |
|----|------------------|
| Low (acidic) | Metals more mobile, toxic |
| Neutral | Moderate mobility |
| High (basic) | Metals less mobile |

## Remediation Techniques

| Method | How it works |
|--------|-------------|
| **Phytoremediation** | Plants absorb pollutants |
| **Bioremediation** | Microbes break down toxins |
| **Soil washing** | Remove contaminants |
| **Excavation** | Remove soil entirely |
| **Stabilization** | Immobilize contaminants |

## Plastic Pollution

- Breaks into microplastics
- Takes 100-1000 years to degrade
- Enters food chain
- Found everywhere on Earth

> üéØ **Key Point:** Prevention is easier and cheaper than remediation!

slides.title: Greenhouse Effect
slides.content:
# Greenhouse Effect üå°Ô∏è

## Natural vs Enhanced

### Natural Greenhouse Effect

```
    ‚òÄÔ∏è Sun
     ‚Üì Solar radiation
    [Atmosphere] ‚Üê Some heat trapped
     ‚Üì              by greenhouse gases
    üåç Earth     ‚Üí This keeps Earth warm!
                   (Without it: -18¬∞C)
```

### Enhanced Greenhouse Effect

Human activities increase greenhouse gases ‚Üí More heat trapped ‚Üí Global warming

## Major Greenhouse Gases

| Gas | Formula | Sources | GWP* |
|-----|---------|---------|------|
| Carbon dioxide | CO‚ÇÇ | Fossil fuels | 1 |
| Methane | CH‚ÇÑ | Livestock, landfills | 28 |
| Nitrous oxide | N‚ÇÇO | Agriculture, industry | 265 |
| CFCs | CFC-11 | Refrigerants (old) | 4,660 |
| Water vapor | H‚ÇÇO | Natural (climate feedback) | - |

*GWP = Global Warming Potential (100-year, relative to CO‚ÇÇ)

## CO‚ÇÇ Increase

| Year | CO‚ÇÇ (ppm) |
|------|----------|
| Pre-industrial | 280 |
| 1960 | 315 |
| 2000 | 370 |
| 2023 | 420+ |

## Consequences

| Effect | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| Rising temperatures | ~1.1¬∞C increase already |
| Sea level rise | Melting ice, thermal expansion |
| Extreme weather | Hurricanes, droughts |
| Ocean acidification | CO‚ÇÇ dissolves, lowers pH |
| Ecosystem changes | Species migration/extinction |

> üí° **Key Insight:** CO‚ÇÇ stays in atmosphere for hundreds of years!

slides.title: Ozone Layer
slides.content:
# Ozone Layer üõ°Ô∏è

## The Ozone Layer

Located in **stratosphere** (15-35 km altitude)

```
    O‚ÇÉ (ozone) absorbs UV radiation
    
    Protects life from harmful UV-B and UV-C
```

## Ozone Formation and Destruction (Natural)

### Formation
```
O‚ÇÇ + UV light ‚Üí 2O
O + O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí O‚ÇÉ
```

### Natural destruction
```
O‚ÇÉ + UV ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ + O
O + O‚ÇÉ ‚Üí 2O‚ÇÇ
```

Balance maintained naturally!

## Ozone Depleting Substances (ODS)

### The Problem: CFCs

```
CCl‚ÇÉF + UV ‚Üí CCl‚ÇÇF + Cl
(CFC-11)

Cl + O‚ÇÉ ‚Üí ClO + O‚ÇÇ
ClO + O ‚Üí Cl + O‚ÇÇ
‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
Net: O‚ÇÉ + O ‚Üí 2O‚ÇÇ
```

**One Cl atom destroys ~100,000 ozone molecules!**

## Ozone Hole

- Discovered 1985 (Antarctica)
- Seasonal (worst in spring)
- CFCs accumulate at poles
- Ice clouds promote reactions

## Montreal Protocol (1987)

- International treaty to phase out ODS
- CFCs being replaced by HFCs
- Ozone layer is recovering!

## UV Radiation Effects

| UV Type | Wavelength | Effect |
|---------|------------|--------|
| UV-A | 315-400 nm | Skin aging |
| UV-B | 280-315 nm | Sunburn, skin cancer |
| UV-C | 100-280 nm | Very dangerous (blocked) |

> üéØ **Success Story:** Montreal Protocol shows international cooperation works!

slides.title: Acid Rain
slides.content:
# Acid Rain üåßÔ∏è

## What is Acid Rain?

Rainfall with pH below 5.6 (natural rain ~ 5.6 due to CO‚ÇÇ)

## Formation

### Sulfuric Acid
```
S (in coal) + O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí SO‚ÇÇ
SO‚ÇÇ + H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí H‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÉ (sulfurous acid)
2SO‚ÇÇ + O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí 2SO‚ÇÉ
SO‚ÇÉ + H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí H‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÑ (sulfuric acid)
```

### Nitric Acid
```
N‚ÇÇ + O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí 2NO (in engines)
2NO + O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí 2NO‚ÇÇ
NO‚ÇÇ + H‚ÇÇO + ¬ΩO‚ÇÇ ‚Üí HNO‚ÇÉ
```

## pH of Precipitation

| Type | pH | Example |
|------|----|---------|
| Pure water | 7.0 | Neutral |
| Normal rain | 5.0-5.6 | CO‚ÇÇ dissolved |
| Acid rain | < 5.0 | Polluted areas |
| Severe | < 4.0 | Industrial regions |

## Effects of Acid Rain

### On Ecosystems
- Fish die (pH < 4.5)
- Aluminum leaches from soil (toxic to plants)
- Forests damaged (needle loss)

### On Materials
- Marble and limestone dissolve:
```
CaCO‚ÇÉ + H‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÑ ‚Üí CaSO‚ÇÑ + H‚ÇÇO + CO‚ÇÇ
```
- Metal corrosion accelerated
- Historical monuments damaged

## Solutions

| Method | How it works |
|--------|-------------|
| Scrubbers | Remove SO‚ÇÇ from emissions |
| Catalytic converters | Reduce NO‚Çì from vehicles |
| Low-sulfur fuel | Reduce S emissions |
| Liming lakes | Neutralize acidity |

> üí° **Progress:** SO‚ÇÇ emissions in developed countries have decreased 70%+ since 1980!

slides.title: Green Chemistry
slides.content:
# Green Chemistry üåø

## What is Green Chemistry?

Designing chemical products and processes that reduce or eliminate hazardous substances.

## The 12 Principles of Green Chemistry

| # | Principle | Description |
|---|-----------|-------------|
| 1 | **Prevention** | Prevent waste, not treat it |
| 2 | **Atom Economy** | Maximize atoms in product |
| 3 | **Less Hazardous Synthesis** | Safer chemicals |
| 4 | **Designing Safer Chemicals** | Minimal toxicity |
| 5 | **Safer Solvents** | Reduce solvent use |
| 6 | **Energy Efficiency** | Minimize energy |
| 7 | **Renewable Feedstocks** | Sustainable raw materials |
| 8 | **Reduce Derivatives** | Fewer synthetic steps |
| 9 | **Catalysis** | Use catalysts over stoichiometric |
| 10 | **Degradable Products** | Design for breakdown |
| 11 | **Real-time Analysis** | Monitor processes |
| 12 | **Inherently Safer** | Minimize accident potential |

## Atom Economy

```
% Atom Economy = (MW of desired product / MW of all reactants) √ó 100%
```

**Example: Addition reaction**
```
A + B ‚Üí C (100% atom economy)
```

**vs. Substitution:**
```
A + B ‚Üí C + D (leaving group wasted)
```

## Green Chemistry Examples

| Traditional | Green Alternative |
|-------------|------------------|
| Organic solvents | Water, supercritical CO‚ÇÇ |
| Petroleum feedstocks | Biomass |
| Toxic reagents | Safer alternatives |
| High temperature | Catalysts, enzymes |

## Bioplastics

- Made from renewable sources
- Biodegradable
- Examples: PLA from corn starch

> üéØ **Vision:** Make the chemical industry sustainable for future generations!
